Description: Taleo Corp. agreed to pay the United States $6.49 million to resolve allegations that it knowingly caused false claims to be submitted to the Transportation Security Administration for a software contract.

TAP Pharmaceutical agreed to pay a total of $875 million to resolve a  case involving fraudulent pricing and improper marketing of its prostate cancer drug Lupron. The amount included a $290 million criminal fine for violating the Prescription Drug Marketing Act; a $559.5 million False Claims Act civil settlement ; and $25.5 million in payments to state governments.  TAP was formerly a joint venture of Takeda Pharmaceutical and Abbott Laboratories; the companies dissolved the venture in 2008, and Takeda took over most of its operations.

Hospital service provider TeamHealth Holdings, as successor in interest to IPC Healthcare Inc., f/k/a IPC The Hospitalists Inc., agreed to resolve allegations that IPC violated the False Claims Act by billing Medicare, Medicaid, the Defense Health Agency and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program for higher and more expensive levels of medical service than were actually performed (a practice known as up-coding).

The Technological Research and Development Authority  agreed to pay $15 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act in connection with grants from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Economic Development Administration of the Department of Commerce. TRDA, which was created by the Florida legislature as a special district, owns and operates a system of incubator facilities to nurture small businesses by providing low-rent office space and business development assistance.

Telephonics Corporation agreed to pay the United States $800,000 to resolve charges that the company failed to disclose payments to a Greek representative in connection with two contracts financed under the government's Foreign Military Financing program.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Tenet HealthCare paid the United States $4.3 million to settle allegations that five of its Florida hospitals violated the False Claims Act through upcoding. The five hospitals were Coral Gables Hospital, Parkway Regional Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Hollywood Medical Center, Hialeah Hospital and Florida Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale.
Tenet Healthcare Corporation, operator of a large hospital chain, agreed to pay the United States $900 million for alleged unlawful billing practices.

A major U.S. hospital chain, Tenet Healthcare Corporation, and two of its Atlanta-area subsidiaries agreed to pay over $513 million to resolve criminal charges and civil claims relating to a scheme to defraud the United States and to pay kickbacks in exchange for patient referrals. Tenet HealthSystem Medical Inc. and its subsidiaries entered into a non-prosecution agreement while two other Tenet subsidiaries, Atlanta Medical Center Inc. and North Fulton Medical Center Inc., agreed to plead guilty to conspiracy to defraud the United States and to pay health care kickbacks and bribes in violation of the Anti-Kickback Statute.
Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States $42.75 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by overbilling the federal Medicare program.

Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States $22.5 million to resolve allegations that one of its facilities improperly billed Medicare for millions of dollars for referrals provided by doctors with whom the hospital had prohibited financial arrangements.

One hundred thirty-nine hospitals currently or formerly operated by Tenet Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay the United States and 22 states $17 million to settle allegations that the facilities overcharged federal health care programs in connection with laboratory services.

Two orthopedic clinics agreed to pay a combined $1.85 million to resolve state and federal False Claims Act allegations that they knowingly billed state and federal health care programs for reimported osteoarthritis medications, known as viscosupplements.

The Justice Department announced that a number of related entities and individuals agreed to pay $2,883,947 to resolve allegations that they falsely claimed disadvantaged business status on a number of federally-funded transportation projects.  These entities are Dayton-based TesTech, Inc. and its owner, Sherif Aziz, and Dayton-based CESO Testing Technology, Inc., CESO International, LLC, and CESO, Inc. and their owners, David and Shery Oakes.

Company: Teva Pharmaceuticals USA Inc. and  IVAX LLC
Description: Pharmaceutical manufacturer Teva Pharmaceuticals USA Inc. and a subsidiary, IVAX LLC, agreed to pay the government and the state of Illinois $27.6 million for allegedly violating the False Claims Act by making payments to induce prescriptions of an anti-psychotic drug for Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries.

Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: Texaco, Inc. agreed to pay $43 million to resolve claims that the oil company underpaid royalties due for oil produced on Federal and Indian leases from January 1, 1980 to December 31, 1998.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Company: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center
Description: The Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center agreed to pay the United States $2.3 million to settle allegations that it  overbilled Medicare, Medicaid and TRICARE - the military's health care program.
Company failed to report production on multiple wells/leases for 34 production months.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: Toshiba Corporation reached a settlement with the United States as part of a class action suit in connection with the company's sale of defective laptop computers to government agencies. The settlement also released Toshiba from liability under the False Claims Act for the sale of defective laptop computers. In addition to paying the United States $23 million, Toshiba agreed to provide the government with $10.5 million in coupons from the company for the purchase of Toshiba products.

Total Fina S.A., Total Minatome Corporation, Total Exploration Production USA Inc., Fina Oil and Chemical Company, Elf Exploration Inc., Total E&P USA Inc. and their affiliates agreed to pay the United States $15 million to resolve claims that the companies violated the False Claims Act by knowingly underpaying royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and Indian leases.
Touro Infirmary, a New Orleans Hospital, agreed to pay the United States $1.75 million to settle allegations that it submitted false claims to the Medicare program.

Company: Toyo Ink SC Holdings Co. Ltd.
Description: Japan-based Toyo Ink SC Holdings Co. Ltd. and various affiliated entities agreed to pay $45 million, plus interest, to settle allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly failing to pay antidumping and countervailing duties.

Trend Area Mental Health, Developmental and Substance Abuse Services agreed to pay the United States $485,000 to settle allegations that the Henderson, North Carolina-based company overbilled Medicaid.

Tri-City Medical Center, a hospital located in Oceanside, California, agreed to pay $3,278,464 to resolve allegations that it violated the Stark Law and the False Claims Act by maintaining financial arrangements with community-based physicians and physician groups that violated the Medicare program's prohibition on financial relationships between hospitals and referring physicians.

Quorum Health Group successor company, Triad Hospitals of Dallas, and Quorum subsidiary, Gadsden Regional Medical Center, agreed to pay the United States $428,343 to settle claims that they defrauded Medicare.
The United States entered into a settlement with a New Jersey hospital involving allegations that the hospital defrauded Medicare.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Fifty-five hospitals in 21 states agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $34 million to settle allegations that they submitted false claims to Medicare for kyphoplasty, a minimally-invasive procedure used to treat certain spinal fractures that often are due to osteoporosis.
TriWest Healthcare Alliance Corporation, a contractor to TRICARE Management Activity, agreed to pay $10 million to resolve civil false claims allegations.

Fifty-five hospitals in 21 states agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $34 million to settle allegations that they submitted false claims to Medicare for kyphoplasty, a minimally-invasive procedure used to treat certain spinal fractures that often are due to osteoporosis.

The Department of Justice resolved a $237 million judgment against Tuomey Healthcare System for illegally billing the Medicare program for services referred by physicians with whom the hospital had improper financial relationships.  Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the United States was to receive $72.4 million and Tuomey, based in Sumter, South Carolina, was to be sold to Palmetto Health, a multi-hospital healthcare system based in Columbia, South Carolina.
Turner Construction Company agreed to pay the United States $6.6 million to settle allegations that it submitted false claims by failing to pass along credits along to the federal government.
Ultralife Corporation, formerly known as Ultralife Batteries Inc., agreed to pay $2.7 million to resolve allegations that the battery manufacturer violated the False Claims Act.

Union Oil Company of California (Unocal) agreed to pay $21.5 million to resolve claims under the False Claims Act and administrative claims that the company underpaid royalties due for oil produced on federal and Indian leases from 1980 to December 31, 1998.
Union Pacific Resources Company agreed to pay $2.7 million to resolve claims that it underpaid royalties due for oil produced on Federal and Indian leases from January 1, 1988, to December 31, 1998.
Unisys Corporation agreed to pay the United States $1,430,000 to settle claims that it failed to disclose information to the government during 1990 contract negotiations.

Nine hospitals agreed to pay the United States more than $9.4 million to settle allegations that the health care facilities submitted false claims to Medicare. The settlements resolved allegations that the hospitals overcharged Medicare between 2000 and 2008 when performing kyphoplasty, a minimally-invasive procedure used to treat certain spinal fractures that often are due to osteoporosis. In many cases, the procedure can be performed safely as a less costly out-patient procedure, but the government contends that the hospitals performed the procedure on an in-patient basis in order to increase their Medicare billings.

United Parcel Service Inc. agreed to pay $25 million to resolve allegations that it submitted false claims to the federal government in connection with its delivery of Next Day Air overnight packages.

United Shore Financial Services LLC agreed to pay the United States $48 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.

The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio found United Technologies Corporation liable for over $473 million in damages and penalties arising out of a contract to provide the Air Force with fighter aircraft engines for F-15 and F-16 aircraft between 1985 and 1990. The company later appealed and won a reduction in the damages to just over $11 million. See https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/101829/000010182916000080/a2016-06x3010xq.htm#sBCDF771A6C12137053F7A004CF150682
United Healthcare Insurance Company agreed to pay the United States $3.5 million to settle allegations that the company defrauded the Medicare program.

Universal Health Services Inc. and two subsidiaries reached a settlement in a False Claims Act lawsuit with the United States and the Commonwealth of Virginia under which UHS and its subsidiaries, Keystone Education and Youth Services LLC and Keystone Marion LLC, which did business as the Keystone Marion Youth Center, a residential facility in Marion, Va., agreed to pay $6.85 million to the United States and the commonwealth to settle allegations that they provided substandard psychiatric counseling and treatment to adolescents in violation of Medicaid requirements, falsified records and submitted false claims to the Medicaid program. By the time of the settlement UHS had closed the Marion facility.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Company: University Medical Center of Southern Nevada
Description: University Medical Center of Southern Nevada, a Las Vegas hospital, agreed to pay the United States $1,163,488 to settle allegations that it submitted false diagnosis codes to Medicare.

The University of Alabama at Birmingham and two related entities agreed to pay the United States $3.39 million to settle allegations that they violated the False Claims Act with respect to claims submitted in connection with the school's health science research activities.

The University of Florida agreed to pay the United States $19.875 million to settle allegations that the university improperly charged the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services for salary and administrative costs on hundreds of federal grants.

Company: University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey
Description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey agreed to pay the United States $2 million to resolve federal civil fraud allegations that its hospital defrauded Medicaid.

Company: University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey
Description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey agreed to pay the government $8.3 million to settle allegations that it illegally paid kickbacks to cardiologists and caused the submission of false claims to Medicare.
The University of Phoenix agreed to pay the United States $67.5 million to resolve allegations that its student recruitment policies violated the False Claims Act.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Seven hospitals agreed to pay the United States more than $6.3 million to settle allegations that the facilities unlawfully charged federal health care programs for surgical procedures using experimental cardiac devices.
Urocor Inc. agreed to pay the United States $9 million to resolve claims that the company improperly charged Medicare and other federal health programs for certain tests it performed.

URS E & C Holdings Inc., a successor in interest to the global design and construction company Washington Group International Inc., agreed to pay $9 million to settle allegations that WGI submitted false claims in connection with United States Agency for International Development contracts.

U.S. Bank agreed to pay $200 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.

U.S. Investigations Services Inc. and its parent company, Altegrity, agreed to settle allegations that USIS violated the False Claims Act for conduct involving a contract for background investigations that USIS held with the U.S. Office of Personnel Management.  The companies agreed to forgo their right to collect payments that they claim were owed by OPM, valued at least at $30 million, in exchange for a release of liability under the FCA.

U.S. Renal Care agreed to pay $7.3 million to resolve allegations that Dialysis Corporation of America, which it acquired in 2010, violated the False Claims Act by submitting false claims to the Medicare program for more Epogen than was actually administered to dialysis patients at DCA facilities.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Vantage Oncology LLC agreed to pay the government more than $2.08 million to settle allegations that it submitted false claims to Medicare for radiation oncology services performed at its Illinois centers from 2007 through June 2012.

Vascular Solutions Inc. agreed to pay $520,000 to resolve allegations that it caused false claims to be submitted to federal health programs by marketing a medical device for the ablation (or sealing) of perforator veins without FDA approval and despite the failure of its own clinical trial.

Vector Planning and Services Inc., an information technology, systems engineering, program management and consulting firm headquartered in Chantilly, Va. , agreed to pay the government $6.5 million to settle False Claims Act allegations that the company inflated claims for payment under several Navy contracts.

Nursing home chain Vencor Inc. and Ventas Inc., a related real estate investment trust, agreed to pay the United States $104.5 million to resolve civil claims that Vencor knowingly submitted false claims to Medicare, Medicaid, and TRICARE, the military's health care program. Among the allegations were inadequate staffing, improper care of decubitus ulcers, and failure to meet resident's dietary needs.

Verizon Communications Inc. paid the United States $93,525,410.96 in order to resolve allegations that the company overcharged the General Services Administration on invoices dealing with government-wide voice and data telecommunications services contracts.

Vibra Healthcare LLC, a national hospital chain headquartered in Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, agreed to $32.7 million, plus interest, to resolve claims that it violated the False Claims Act by billing Medicare for medically unnecessary services.

Visiting Physicians Association agreed to pay the United States and the state of Michigan $9.5 million to settle allegations that the association violated the False Claims Act by submitting false claims to Medicare, TRICARE and the Michigan Medicaid program.

Company: VMware Inc. and Carahsoft Technology Corporation
Description: VMware Inc. and Carahsoft Technology Corporation agreed to pay $75.5 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by misrepresenting their commercial pricing practices and overcharging the government on VMware software products and related services.

Hospice Care of Kansas LLC and its parent company, Ft. Worth, Texas-based Voyager HospiceCare Inc., agreed to pay $6.1 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by submitting claims to the Medicare program for ineligible hospice services.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. agreed to pay $2,866,904 to settle allegations that the company submitted false prescription claims to government health insurance programs by dispensing partial prescriptions due to insufficient stock while billing the government health insurance programs (Medicaid, Tricare Management Activity, and the Federal Employee Health Benefits Program) for the full quantities.

Walgreen Co. agreed to pay $35 million to settle claims that from 2001 to 2005 it improperly switched patients to different versions of the prescriptions drugs Ranitidine, Fluoxetine and Eldepryl in order to increase its reimbursement from Medicaid.
National retail pharmacy chain Walgreens paid the United States and four participating states $9.9 million to resolve allegations of falsely billing the Medicaid program.

The Walgreens pharmacy chain paid the United States and participating states $7.9 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by  offering illegal inducements to beneficiaries of government health care programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, TRICARE and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, in the form of gift cards, gift checks and other similar promotions to transfer their prescriptions to Walgreens pharmacies.

Walter Investment Management Corp. agreed to pay $29.63 million to resolve allegations that through its subsidiaries -- Reverse Mortgage Solution Inc., REO Management Solutions LLC and RMS Asset Management Solutions LLC -- it violated the False Claims Act in connection with participation in the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Home Equity Conversion Mortgages program, which insures reverse mortgage loans.
Company failed to report production information on 28 federal properties for as many as 78 months.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: Ward Diesel Filter Systems Inc. agreed to pay the United States $628,000 to resolve allegations that it knowingly submitted false claims to federal agencies under a contract to provide diesel exhaust filtering systems for fire engines through the General Services Administration's Multiple Award Schedule program.
Warren Hospital in Phillipsburg, N.J., agreed to pay the United States $7.5 million to settle allegations that it improperly increased charges in order to obtain enhanced reimbursement from Medicare.
Company knowingly or willfully failed to pas Indian gas royalties over multiple reporting periods.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: Washington River Protection Solutions LLC agreed to pay the United States $5.275 million to settle allegations that WRPS knowingly submitted false claims to the Department of Energy for overtime and premium pay and also failed to comply with the contract's internal audit requirements.

California-based C.R. Laurence Co. Inc., Florida-based Southeastern Aluminum Products Inc. and Texas-based Waterfall Group LLC agreed to pay $2,300,000, $650,000 and $100,000, respectively, to resolve a lawsuit brought by the United States under the False Claims Act alleging that the companies engaged in schemes to evade customs duties on imports of aluminum extrusions from the People's Republic of China.

Fifty-five hospitals in 21 states agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $34 million to settle allegations that they submitted false claims to Medicare for kyphoplasty, a minimally-invasive procedure used to treat certain spinal fractures that often are due to osteoporosis.

WellCare Health Plans Inc. agreed to pay $137.5 million to the federal government and nine states to resolve four lawsuits alleging violations of the False Claims Act by falsely inflating the amount it claimed to be spending on medical care in order to avoid returning money to Medicaid and other programs in various states, including the Florida Medicaid and Florida Healthy Kids programs; knowingly retaining overpayments it had received from Florida Medicaid for infant care; and falsifying data that misrepresented the medical conditions of patients and the treatments they received.

Blue Cross of California (BCC) and its parent company WellPoint Health Networks agreed to pay the United States $9,250,000 to resolve allegations that BCC, which had a contract with the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to process Medicare claims in California, knowingly falsified data regarding its performance of cost report audits.

The Department of Justice announced the settlement of civil mortgage fraud claims against Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. stemming from its participation in the Federal Housing Administration Direct Endorsement Lender Program. In the settlement, Wells Fargo agreed to pay $1.2 billion and admitted, acknowledged and accepted responsibility for, among other things, certifying to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, during the period from May 2001 through December 2008, that certain residential home mortgage loans were eligible for FHA insurance when in fact they were not, resulting in the government having to pay FHA insurance claims when some of those loans defaulted.

Fourteen hospitals located in New York, Mississippi, North Carolina, Washington, Indiana, Missouri and Florida agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $12 million to settle allegations that the health care facilities submitted false claims to Medicare relating to lyphplasty services.

Company: West Chester Hospital and UC Health
Description: Cincinnati-based West Chester Hospital and its parent company, UC Health, agreed to pay $4.1 million to settle allegations that West Chester Hospital violated the False Claims Act by billing federal health care programs for costs associated with medically unnecessary spine surgeries.
West Jefferson Medical Center agreed to pay the United States and the State of Louisiana $3.3 million to resolve allegations that the hospital overcharged the Medicaid program.

Four emergency physician groups agreed to pay the United States and various states a total of more than $2.6 million to settle allegations that the groups received overpayments based on false claims submitted by their billing company.

Western Energy Company, operator of the Rosebud Mine on federal coal leases outside of Billings, Montana paid the United States more than $12 million in mineral royalties and accrued interest as the result of a settlement agreement announced by the Justice Department and Department of the Interior.
Agency: Interior Department referral to the Justice Department

Description: Several California companies and individuals that formerly supplied beef to the National School Lunch Program agreed to settle allegations of inhumane handling of cattle, circumventing appropriate inspection of nonambulatory disabled ("downer") cattle and false representations regarding their eligibility to process beef.
Wheaton Community Hospital, the City of Wheaton, Minn. and Dr. Stanley Gallagher agreed to pay $846,461 to settle allegations that their hospital admission practices violated the False Claims Act.

Williams International Co., LLC agreed to pay $2.1 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act in the manufacture and delivery of non-conforming engines for target drones that the company caused to be sold to the United States Navy.

Company: William Beaumont Hospital d/b/a Beaumont Health System
Description: The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

A Texas highway construction firm agreed to pay the United States $3 million to resolve claims that it knowingly violated the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE) contracting requirements on federally-funded Texas highway construction projects.

Williston Rescue Squad Inc. agreed to pay the United States $800,000 to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by making false claims for payment to Medicare for ambulance transports.

The Department of Justice reached 70 settlements involving 457 hospitals in 43 states for more than $250 million related to cardiac devices that were implanted in Medicare patients in violation of Medicare coverage requirements.

Workforce Central Florida and Workforce Central Florida Foundation Inc. agreed to pay the United States $3,483,664.19 to settle claims that they defrauded the U.S. Department of Labor, and U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
Company failed to provide documents essential to an audit.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: The Justice Department announced that the court presiding over WorldCom, Inc.'s bankruptcy petitions approved the company's agreement to pay the government $27 million to settle claims that it defrauded the General Services Administration from 1999 to the present. In addition, MCI was to pay $670,000 in credits to GSA.

W.W. Grainger Inc. agreed to pay the United States $70 million to resolve allegations that it submitted false claims under contracts with the General Services Administration and the U.S. Postal Services for hardware products and other supplies.
W.W. Grainger Inc. paid the United States $6 million to settle allegations that it submitted false claims for facilities maintenance and related products.
Company made payments an average 44 days late over a 3-year period.
Agency: Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Secondary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Novo Nordisk Inc. agreed to pay $58.65 million to resolve allegations that the company failed to comply with the FDA-mandated Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) for its Type II diabetes medication Victoza. The resolution included disgorgement of $12.15 million for alleged violations of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act from 2010 to 2012 and a payment of $46.5 million for alleged violations of the False Claims Act from 2010 to 2014.

Company: CHRISTUS St. Vincent Regional Medical Center
Description: CHRISTUS St. Vincent Regional Medical Center and its partner CHRISTUS Health agreed to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by making illegal donations to county governments, which were used to fund the state share of Medicaid payments to the hospital.

Mylan Inc. and Mylan Specialty L.P. agreed to pay $465 million to resolve claims that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly misclassifying EpiPen as a generic drug to avoid paying rebates owed primarily to Medicaid.

Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc. agreed to a $9.2 million settlement of allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly overbilling the government for labor on U.S. Navy and Coast Guard ships at its shipyards in Pascagoula, Mississippi.

ADS Inc. and its subsidiaries agreed to pay the United States $16 million to settle allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly conspiring with and causing purported small businesses to submit false claims for payment in connection with fraudulently obtained small business contracts.

PHH Corp. PHH Mortgage Corp. and PHH Home Loans agreed to pay the United States $74,453,802 to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Federal Housing Administration, guaranteed by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, and purchased by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac that did not meet applicable requirements.

Hyperion Foundation (a Georgia not-for-profit entity), AltaCare Corporation (a Georgia corporation engaged in nursing home management) and related companies Long Term Care Services Inc. and Sentry Healthcare Acquirors Inc. agreed to pay the United States a total of $1.25 million to resolve allegations of false claims to Medicare and the Mississippi Medicaid program for providing grossly substandard care to residents at the Oxford Health and Rehabilitation nursing home in Lumberton, Mississippi, from late 2005 through mid-2012, when it was operated by AltaCare, under a contract with Hyperion.

Chemed Corporation and various wholly-owned subsidiaries, including Vitas Hospice Services LLC and Vitas Healthcare Corporation, agreed to pay $75 million to resolve a government lawsuit alleging that defendants submitted false claims for hospice services to Medicare.

Company: Zoladz Construction Company Inc., Arsenal Contracting LLC and Alliance Contracting LLC
Description: Three western New York contractors agreed to pay the United States more than $3 million to settle allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by improperly obtaining federal set-aside contracts designated for service-disabled veteran-owned (SDVO) small businesses.

SolarCity Corporation agreed to pay $29.5 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by submitting inflated claims on behalf of itself and affiliated investment funds to the U.S. Department of the Treasury pursuant to Section 1603 of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.

Company: Family Medicine Centers of South Carolina LLC

Description: The company settled allegations that it failed to follow specifications in making Kevlar used in helmets and body armor for the U.S. military.
Burlington Resources Inc. agreed to pay the United States $97.5 million to resolve claims that it underpaid royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal and Indian leases.

Abbott Laboratories and two of its units agreed to pay a total of $600 million in the first combined civil settlement and criminal conviction arising from Operation Headwaters, an undercover investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service and the Office of the Inspector General for HHS, in which federal agents created a fictitious medical supplier known as Southern Medical Distributors. During its operation, various manufacturers, including Abbott's Ross Products Division, offered kickbacks to undercover agents to purchase the manufacturers' products and then advised them how to fraudulently bill the government for those items. In addition to a $382 million in civil federal Medicare and Medicaid recoveries, the states recovered $18 million in state Medicaid funds in connection with the federal government's claims. Abbott subsidiary C G Nutritionals also paid $200 million in criminal fines.

Bayer Corporation paid $143 million to resolve a whistleblower's allegations that it defrauded the Medicaid and Public Health Service programs by relabeling products sold to a health maintenance organization at deeply discounted rates and then concealing the discounts to avoid paying rebates, in violation of the Medicaid Rebate program. In addition, Bayer paid $108 million to reimburse state Medicaid programs for the same conduct.

Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest operator of nursing homes, agreed to pay $170 million to settle allegations that it defrauded Medicare by fabricating records to make it appear that nurses were devoting much more time to Medicare patients than they actually were.

Company: Fresenius Medical Care (fka National Medical Care)
Description: Fresenius Medical Care, formerly known as National Medical Care,  agreed to pay a $101 million criminal fine and a $385 million civil settlement to resolve allegations that the company submitted false claims for laboratory tests and conspired to pay illegal kickbacks.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Eastern District of New York

Company: Progressive Casualty Insurance Co. and Progressive Garden State Insurance Co.
Description: Two insurance companies that are part of one of the largest providers of automobile insurance in the United States agreed to pay more than $2 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by causing Medicare and Medicaid to pay for claims for which the companies were responsible.

Description: Pacific Architects and Engineers, LLC agreed to pay the United States $5 million to resolve allegations that it knowingly failed to follow vetting requirements for personnel working in Afghanistan under a State Department contract for labor services.

MediSys Health Network, Inc., which owns and operates Jamaica Hospital Medical Center and Flushing Hospital Medical Center, two hospitals in Queens, New York, agreed to pay $4 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by engaging in improper financial relationships with referring physicians.

Description: Galena Biopharma Inc. agreed to pay more than $7.55 million to resolve allegations that it paid kickbacks to doctors to induce them to prescribe its fentanyl-based drug Abstral. The allegations arose from a whistleblower suit filed under the False Claims Act.

The settlement resolved claims that US Bioservices violated the Anti-Kickback Statute and the False Claims Act by participating in a kickback scheme with Novartis PharmaceuticalS Corp. relating to the latter's drug Exjade.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Sightpath Medical, Inc. (n/k/a Sightpath Medical, LLC), TLC Vision Corporation (n/k/a TLC Vision (USA, LLC) and their former CEO agreed to pay more than $12 million to the United States to resolve kickback allegations under the False Claims Act.
Midasco, LLC agreed to pay $450,000 to settle False Claims Act allegations related to work on the Virginia I-495 HOV/HOT Lanes Project.

West Palm Beach, Florida-based government contractor Academy Medical, LLC and its owners agreed to pay $335,000 to resolve allegations that they took advantage of federal contracting opportunities reserved for certified service-disabled veteran-owned small businesses.

Description: Celgene Corp. agreed to pay $280 million to settle fraud allegations related to the promotion of two cancer treatment drugs for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

Description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. paid $1.65 million to resolve allegations that it violated the federal False Claims Act when it knowingly submitted claims for reimbursement to California's Medi-Cal program that were not supported by applicable diagnosis and documentation requirements.

MAK Healthcare PC d/b/a Multicare Plus

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Northern District of New York

Company: Andover Subacute and Rehab Center Services Two Inc.

Description: CareCore settled allegations that it authorized medical diagnostic procedures paid for with Medicare and Medicaid funds over a period of at least eight years without properly assessing whether the procedures were necessary or reasonable.

DaVita Rx LLC, a nationwide pharmacy that specializes in serving patients with severe kidney disease, agreed to pay a total of $63.7 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations relating to improper billing practices and unlawful financial inducements to federal healthcare program beneficiaries.

21st Century Oncology Inc. and certain of its subsidiaries and affiliates agreed to pay $26 million to the government to resolve a self-disclosure relating to the submission of false attestations regarding the company's use of electronic health records software and separate allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by submitting, or causing the submission of, claims for certain services provided pursuant to referrals from physicians with whom they had improper financial relationships.

IBERIABANK Corporation, IBERIABANK and IBERIABANK Mortgage Company agreed to pay the United States $11,692,149 to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by falsely certifying they were complying with Federal requirements in order to obtain insurance on mortgage loans from the Federal Housing Administration.

Pine Creek Medical Center LLC, a physician-owned hospital serving the Dallas/Fort Worth area, agreed to pay $7.5 million to resolve claims that it violated the False Claims Act by paying physicians kickbacks in the form of marketing services in exchange for surgical referrals.

Description: Prime Healthcare Services, Inc., Prime Healthcare Foundation, Inc., and Prime Healthcare Management, Inc. as well as Prime's Founder and Chief Executive Officer, Dr. Prem Reddy, agreed to pay the United States $65 million to settle allegations that 14 Prime hospitals in California knowingly submitted false claims to Medicare by admitting patients who required only less costly, outpatient care and by billing for more expensive patient diagnoses than the patients had (a practice known as up-coding). Under the settlement agreement, Dr. Reddy will pay $3,250,000 and Prime will pay $61,750,000.

William Beaumont Hospital, a regional hospital system based in the Detroit, Michigan area, agreed to pay $84.5 million to resolve allegations under the False Claims Act of improper relationships with eight referring physicians, resulting in the submission of false claims to the Medicare, Medicaid and TRICARE programs.

The Department of Justice announced that 3M Company agreed to pay $9.1 million to resolve allegations that it knowingly sold the dual-ended Combat Arms Earplugs, Version 2 (CAEv2) to the United States military without disclosing defects that hampered the effectiveness of the hearing protection device.?

Description: Northrop Grumman Systems Corporation agreed to pay a total of $31.65 million to settle civil and criminal investigations into fraud arising out of its Battlefield Airborne Communications Node and Dynamic Re-tasking Capability contracts with the United States Air Force.  NGSC agreed to pay $27.45 million to settle civil allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by overstating the number of hours its employees worked on the contracts.  Additionally, NGSC agreed to forfeit $4.2 million in a separate agreement to resolve a criminal investigation into fraudulent billing on the BACN contract. In exchange for admitting its employees' misconduct, making full restitution, and agreeing to cooperate in the ongoing criminal investigation, no criminal charges were filed against NGSC.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Northern District of New York

Description: AmerisourceBergen Corporation and its subsidiaries AmerisourceBergen Specialty Group, AmerisourceBergen Drug Corporation, Oncology Supply Company, and Medical Initiatives Inc.  agreed to pay $625 million to resolve allegations arising from its operation of a facility that improperly repackaged oncology-supportive injectable drugs into pre-filled syringes and improperly distributed those syringes to physicians treating vulnerable cancer patients.

Universal American Mortgage Company LLC agreed to pay the United States $13.2 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by falsely certifying that it complied with Federal Housing Administration (FHA) mortgage insurance requirements in connection with certain loans.

British Airways and Iberia Airlines agreed to pay $5.8 million to resolve their liability under the False Claims Act for falsely reporting the times they transferred possession of United States mail to foreign postal administrations or other intended recipients under contracts with the United States Postal Service.

Description: MedStar Health Inc. agreed to pay the United States $35 million to settle allegations under the False Claims Act that it paid kickbacks to MidAtlantic Cardiovascular Associates, a cardiology group based in Pikesville, Maryland, in exchange for referrals, through a series of professional services contracts at Union Memorial and Franklin Square Hospitals in Baltimore.

Covidien LP agreed to pay $17,477,947 to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by providing free or discounted practice development and market development support to physicians located in California and Florida to induce purchases of Covidien's vein ablation products.
Northrop Grumman Systems Corporation agreed to pay $5.2 million to resolve its alleged False Claims Act liability for falsely billing labor under contract with the United States Postal Service.

Description: The Department of Justice reached a settlement of its civil forfeiture case against assets owned by Hikmatullah Shadman that he wrongfully acquired as a government contractor in Afghanistan.  Under the terms of the settlement, approximately $25 million will be forfeited to the United States. The civil settlement is part of a global settlement that involved the resolution of a criminal case and False Claims Act allegations.

Company: PhysioHealth Inc. and Dynamic Therapy Services, LLC

Description: Walgreen Co. agreed to pay $3.5 million to the United States and the State of Wisconsin to settle allegations that it submitted claims to Medicaid for stimulant medications without complying with Medicaid rules designed to ensure that stimulants are dispensed for appropriate medical treatment.

Walgreens agreed to pay the United States and state governments a total of $269.2 million to resolve allegations that it improperly billed Medicare, Medicaid, and other federal healthcare programs for hundreds of thousands of insulin pens it knowingly dispensed to program beneficiaries who did not need them and that it overbilled Medicaid by failing to disclose to and charge Medicaid the lower drug prices that Walgreens offered the public through a discount program.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Target Corporation agreed to pay a total of $3,000,000 to resolve allegations that it violated the federal False Claims Act and Massachusetts False Claims Act by submitting claims for payment to Massachusetts' Medicaid program in violation of rules prohibiting Medicaid prescriptions from being automatically refilled.

Opioid manufacturer Insys Therapeutics agreed to a global resolution to settle federal criminal and civil investigations regarding its sale of the powerful opioid Subsys. As part of the criminal resolution, Insys entered into a deferred prosecution agreement, pled guility to five counts of mail fraud, and paid a $2 million fine and $28 million in forfeiture. As part of the civil resolution, Insys agreed to pay $195 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act. Both the criminal and civil investigations stemmed from Insys's payment of kickbacks and other unlawful marketing practices in connection with the marketing of Subsys.

Informatica LLC f/k/a Informatica Corporation agreed to pay $21.57 million to resolve allegations that it caused the government to be overcharged by providing misleading information about its commercial sales practices that was used in General Services Administration contract negotiations.

US WorldMeds LLC agreed to pay $17.5 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks to patients and physicians to improperly induce prescriptions of its drugs, Apokyn and Myobloc.

Astellas Pharma US Inc. agreed to pay $100 million and Amgen Inc. agreed to pay $24.75 million to resolve allegations that they each violated the False Claims Act by illegally paying the Medicare copays for their own products, through purportedly independent foundations that the companies used as mere conduits.

Astellas Pharma US Inc. agreed to pay $100 million and Amgen Inc. agreed to pay $24.75 million to resolve allegations that they each violated the False Claims Act by illegally paying the Medicare copays for their own products, through purportedly independent foundations that the companies used as mere conduits.

Sutter Health LLC, a California-based healthcare services provider, and several affiliated entities, Sutter East Bay Medical Foundation, Sutter Pacific Medical Foundation, Sutter Gould Medical Foundation, and Sutter Medical Foundation, agreed to pay $30 million to resolve allegations that the affiliated entities submitted inaccurate information about the health status of beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Advantage Plans, which resulted in the plans and providers being overpaid.

Three pharmaceutical companies -- Jazz Pharmaceuticals plc, Lundbeck LLC, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc. -- agreed to pay a total of $122.6 million to resolve allegations that they each violated the False Claims Act by illegally paying the Medicare or Civilian Health and Medical Program (ChampVA) copays for their own products, through purportedly independent foundations that the companies used as mere conduits.

Three pharmaceutical companies -- Jazz Pharmaceuticals plc, Lundbeck LLC, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc. -- agreed to pay a total of $122.6 million to resolve allegations that they each violated the False Claims Act by illegally paying the Medicare or Civilian Health and Medical Program (ChampVA) copays for their own products, through purportedly independent foundations that the companies used as mere conduits.

Three pharmaceutical companies -- Jazz Pharmaceuticals plc, Lundbeck LLC, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc. -- agreed to pay a total of $122.6 million to resolve allegations that they each violated the False Claims Act by illegally paying the Medicare or Civilian Health and Medical Program (ChampVA) copays for their own products, through purportedly independent foundations that the companies used as mere conduits.

Duke University agreed to pay the government $112.5 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by submitting grant applications and progress reports that contained falsified research to the National Institutes of Health and to the Environmental Protection Agency.

An Oregon aluminum extrusion manufacturer formerly known as Sapa Profiles Inc. and whose ultimate corporate parent is now the Norwegian company Norsk Hydro agreed to pay $46.9 million to NASA, the Department of Defense, and others to resolve criminal charges and civil claims relating to a 19-year fraud scheme that included falsifying thousands of certifications for aluminum extrusions provided to hundreds of customers. The company agreed to plead guilty to one count of mail fraud, and its immediate parent Hydro Extrusion USA, LLC, formerly known as Sapa Extrusions Inc., entered into a deferred prosecution agreement in connection with a criminal information charging the company with mail fraud.

Description: AstraZeneca agreed to pay $110 million to the state of Texas to settle lawsuits alleging that the company falsely and misleadingly marketed two of its drugs in violation of the Texas Medicaid Fraud Prevention Act.

AstraZeneca argeed to pay $46.5 million to settle multistate allegations that it overcharged state Medicaid programs for pharmaceutical products by underpaying drug rebates owed to the states. Also involved in the settlement was the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-astrazeneca-lp-1

AstraZeneca agreed to pay $24.9 million to state attorneys general and federal agencies to resolve allegations that it caused false and fraudulent claims to be filed with the states as a result of its pricing and marketing misconduct relating to the prostate cancer drug Zoladex and that it failed to provide the state Medicaid programs its best price for the drug as required by law. This was part of a larger $354.9 million civil and criminal settlement negoltiated by the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-astrazeneca-pharmaceuticals-lp

AstraZeneca agreed to pay $2.6 million to settle multistate litigation claiming it violated the False Claims Act by failing to pay appropriate rebates for drugs that were paid for by Medicaid. Also involved in the settlement was the U.S. Justice Department, which made its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-astrazeneca-pharmaceuticals

Company: AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP and AstraZeneca LP
Description: AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP and AstraZeneca LP agreed to pay $2.5 million in settlement of allegations they misreported the average wholesale price of their drugs.

AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis together agreed to pay $10 million as part of a series of settlements between pharmaceutical companies and Hawaii of allegations that they published inflated prices for drugs and thus increased Medicaid costs. The announcement did not specify how that amount would be split among the three companies. Here we assume it was divided evenly among them.

Fifteen members of the Massachusetts orthopedic footwear industry agreed to pay a total of $526,000 in settlement of allegations billing deficiencies resulted in Medicaid overpayments. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.

Diagnostic Laboratory Medicine, Inc. agreed to pay more than $153,000 plus interest in settlement of allegations it billed Medicaid for urine drug tests that were not properly ordered and for purposes not covered by Medicaid, as well as overcharged for the tests and failed to comply with record keeping requirements.
improper bill for orthodontic procedures

The California Attorney General announced a $2.6 million settlement with Diebold Election Systems, Inc.  to resolve a lawsuit that alleged the Texas-based firm provided false information to obtain payments from the state and counties for its electronic voting equipment.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.

Company: Doctor's Choice Medical Equipment of Largo, Inc.
Description: Doctor's Choice Medical Equipment of Largo, Inc. agreed to pay more than $1.38 million in settlement of allegations that it double-billed and submitted false claims for medical equipment sales to Medicare and Medicaid.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Company: Doshi Diagnostic Imaging Services, P.C., and Diagnostic Imaging Group, LLC
Description: Doshi Diagnostic Imaging Services, P.C., and Diagnostic Imaging Group, LLC agreed to pay $15.5 million to resolve allegations that the radiology practice, headquartered on Long Island, submitted false claims to the Medicaid and Medicare programs for diagnostic outpatient imaging services that were not specifically ordered by a treating physician and not medically necessary. The agreement also resolved allegations that the companies engaged in a kickback scheme which violated federal and state laws.
The dental practice and its owner were ordered to pay $717,046 in restitution and civil penalties for improperly billing Medicaid.

E.G.A. Management, Inc.; Haven Consulting, Inc.; AMZ Consulting, Inc.; Electron Marketing, Inc.; Dental Care of Connecticut, Inc.; N.B. Dental, Inc. and their owner agreed to pay $9.9 million in settlement of an alleged fraudulent Medicaid billing scheme involving multiple dental practices.
Several anethesia providers agreed to repay Medicaid payments to settle allegations they double-billed for the same service and multi-unit billed for services that were not documented.

Eckerd Corporation, a national retail pharmacy chain, agreed to pay $3.1 million to settle multistate claims that it overcharged state Medicaid programs when it dispensed partial prescriptions due to insufficient stock but billed for the full quantities prescribed. At the same time, the federal government negotiated a separate $5.8 million settlement on the same issue; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-eckerd-corporation

Education Management Corp. agreed to pay approximately $31 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it violated False Claims Act provisions by falsely certifying that it was in compliance with Title IV of the Higher Education Act and parallel state statutes. This was part of a larger $95 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-education-management-corp. The case announcement did not mention the state figure explicitly but listed the total settlement amount and the other portions, suggesting that the remainder would go to the states.
Educational Service Center agreed to repay a small portion of the public funds it received as sponsor of the closed Electronic Classroom of Tomorrow online charter school.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Elizabethtown Hematology and Oncology, PLC and its owners agreed to pay more than $3.7 million in settlement of allegations they extended chemotherapy treatment times and billed therapies inappropriately to maximize reimbursements.

EMD Serono agreed to pay $44.3 million to settle multistate allegations that the company caused false or fraudulent claims to be submitted to Medicaid programs. The company was accused of paying doctors so that they would prescribe the multiple sclerosis drug Rebif to patients.  The settlement was negotiated together with the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-serono-laboratories-inc

Info Source: Attorney General Reaches $1.86 Million Settlement with Emeritus Corp.; National Leader in Assisted Living Falsely Billed Medicaid, States News Service, August 28, 2007 (via Nexis).

Company: Emeritus Corporation, dba Emeritus Senior Living
Description: Emeritus, an operator of assisted living facilities now owned by Brookdale Senior Living, agreed to pay $587,400 to the federal government for failing to return overpayments it received from Medicaid services. It also paid $391,600 to 18 states (see separate Violation Tracker entry).

Company: Emeritus Corporation, dba Emeritus Senior Living
Description: Emeritus, an operator of assisted living facilities now owned by Brookdale Senior Living, agreed to pay $391,600 to 18 states for failing to return overpayments it received from Medicaid services. This was part of a larger $979,000 settlement involving the federal government.

Company: Empire State Home Care Services, Inc.
Description: improper billing for home health aide services

Encompass Health Corporation (formerly known as HealthSouth Corporation), the nation's largest operator of inpatient rehabilitation facilities (IRFs), agreed to pay $48 million to resolve allegations that some of its IRFs provided inaccurate information to Medicare to maintain their status as an IRF and to earn a higher rate of reimbursement, and that some admissions to its IRFs were not medically necessary.

Qualitest Pharmaceuticals, Inc., a manufacturer of generic pharmaceutical products, and its parent company, Endo Health Solutions, agreed to pay $39 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging unlawful labeling practices; specifically, selling multivitamin tablets said to contain the American Dental Association (ADA) amount of fluoride when they actually contained less than half that amount. Also involved in the settlement was the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-endo-pharmaceuticals-inc-and-vintage-pha

Description: EP Energy Massachusetts, along with its contractors and engineers, agreed to pay a total of $3.25 million in settlement of allegations they overfilled an ash landfill and three wastewater treatment basins in Agawam and West Springfield, failing to pay taxes and falsely certifying that the work was done properly.
ETHEX agreed to pay $574,998 and provide $150,000 in free drugs in settlement of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to pay inflated amounts.

ExxonMobil agreed to repay $2 million it received from the state to clean up gasoline spills at service stations after the state learned that the company had also been reimbursed by private insurance for the work.

DeFelice, Inc., FDR Construction, Maguire Group, and XL Speciality Insurance Co. agreed to pay a total of $2.26 million in settlement of allegations they installed defective storm drains on Interstate 84, in breach of contract. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Ferrandino & Son Inc. agreed to pay $187,095 in restitution and a $50,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations it did not use the correct benchmarks for average snowfall in Connecticut and thus failed to pay snowplow subcontractors a contracted bonus for years with high snowfall.
inflating reported drug prices

Moody's Investors Service, Inc., Standard & Poor's, and Fitch, Inc. agreed to settlements that totalled approximately $900,000 in credits after the state alleged that they misrepresented the meaning of their public bond ratings and gave lower ratings to public bonds, resulting in increased costs of borrowing for the state, cities, towns and school districts. The announcement did not specify how much each company would provide in credits. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.
Floyd Medical Center agreed to repay $1.5 million to Medicaid and $1.37 million to Medicare in settlement of violations of state and federal billing regulations.

Focused Technologies Imaging Services agreed to pay $2.1 million to resolve allegations that it unlawfully outsourced government-funded work to a subcontractor based in Mumbai, India in 2008 and 2009. The outsourcing was illegal because even though FTIS was required to perform the work at a warehouse in Albany, New York, FTIS unlawfully sent personal information of over 16 million people to a foreign business that was unauthorized to receive this information. The outsourcing also resulted in the failure of FTIS to adhere to a requirement that over 50% of the labor hours of the contract be performed by individuals with disabilities.

FORBA Holdings, a dental management company that provided business management and administrative services to 69 clinics nationwide, agreed to pay $9.7 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it caused bills to be submitted to state Medicaid programs for medically unnecessary dental services performed on children. This was part of a larger $24 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-forba-holdings-llc

The Alabama AG announced that a group of six pharmaceutical companies agreed to pay a total of $89 million to settle litigation relating to Medicaid average wholesale prices. The amount to be paid by each company was not revealed. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: Associated Press, Ala. settles suits with 6 drug firms for $89M, May 22, 2009 (via Nexis).

Gannett Fleming agreed to pay $1.525 million to the infrastructure fund, $50,000 to the City of Boston, and forgo $150,000 in payments the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority, in settlement of pending civil claims in connection with the I-90 ceiling collapse, a section the company designed.

Pharmaceutical companies Genentech Inc. and OSI Pharmaceuticals LLC agreed to pay a total of $4.4 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging they made misleading statements about the effectiveness of the drug Tarceva to treat non-small cell lung cancer and thus caused false claims to be submitted to state Medicaid programs. Gentle Smiles and its owner agreed to pay $500,000 to Medicaid in settlement of allegations it improperly charged for palliative care without complying with rules for billing emergency treatment.

Genzyme Corp. agreed to pay $22.28 million to a group of states and the federal government to resolve allegations that it caused false claims to be submitted to government health care programs for use of a slurry version of its Seprafilm adhesion barrier. The Louisiana Attorney General's Office announced that it had obtained a total of $88 million in settlements from 25 pharmaceutical companies to resolve allegations they overcharged the state's Medicaid program.

GlaxoSmithKline agreed to pay $40 million to settle multistate allegations that it defrauded Medicaid programs by relabeling products sold to a health maintenance organization at deeply discounted rates and then concealing the discounts to avoid paying rebates. The federal government reached its own separate $47 million settlement with the company on the same issue; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-smithkline-beecham

GlaxoSmithKline paid $10 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that the company violated the False Claims Act through fraudulent drug pricing and marketing of two anti-emetic drugs, Zofran and Kytril, used primarily in conjunction with oncology and radiation treatment. This was part of a larger $150 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-glaxosmithkline

GSK agreed to pay $418,951 in settlement of allegations it improperly inflated the average wholesale price paid by government health plans for certain of its prescription drugs. The conduct at issue concerned Glaxo's reporting of pricing data that was used by Medicare and Medicaid to set reimbursement amounts for its drugs Kytril and Zofran, injectible anti-nausea drugs used by patients undergoing chemotherapy.
Notes: Attorney General press release: "The settlement, in conjunction with an earlier Federal Settlement, resulted in $418,951.52 being repaid to Georgia's Medicaid program"

International Business Machines Corporation and Curam Software (now owned by IBM) agreed to pay $14.8 million to settle state and federal allegations that they made material misrepresentations during the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange contract award process for the development of Maryland's Health Insurance Exchange website and IT platform. Maryland received $2.8 million of the total. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department (see separate Violation Tracker entry).

Description: ITT Cannon agreed to pay the United States $11 million to settle False Claims Act allegations that it supplied electrical connectors to the military that had not been properly tested.

Jayco and its principals peaded guilty to violating the Solid Waste Act and to the presentment of false claims relating to allegations they did not dump the street sweepings they were contracted to collect at an authorized landfill and fabricated documentation and invoices for loads of waste Jayco never hauled.

King Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $124 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it failed to accurately report its average manufacturer price and its best price for certain pharmaceutical products. The U.S. Department of Justice was also involved in the settlement and issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-king-pharmaceuticals
