Tipton & Unroe, a podiatry practice, agreed to pay $10,000 as part of a settlement of allegations it double-billed Medicaid for certain treatments.
Toshiba Corporation and three of its subsidiaries agreed to pay more than $30 million to California public agencies in settlement of a lawsuit alleging violation of the state False Claims Act.

Toyobo Co. agreed to pay in settlement of a class action suit alleging that the material used in bullet proof vests lost effectiveness before the end of the warranty period. This payment was to Massachusetts law enforcement agencies that had joined the class action suit.
Tri-City Mental Health agreed to pay $556,687 in settlement of allegations it billed Medicaid for services never actually provided.

Info Source: Tri-City Mental Health Center Pays More Than $550,000 to Settle False Claims Allegations, States News Service, March 23, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: Trinity EMS agreed to pay $350,000 penalties and costs in settlement of allegations it billed the Commonwealth for ambulance services that were not staffed by properly-certified EMT employees.

The New York Attorney General announced a $22.4 million with the pharmacy Trinity Homecare LLC, primarily owned by Walgreen Co., that began with a whistleblower claim of improper conduct and false Medicaid billings by the company and led to an expanded investigation by the AG's office . The settlement related to Synagis, an expensive injectable drug for certain at-risk premature infants. The settlement resolved claims of improper prescriptions and billings for patients in New York City, Dutchess, Orange, Rockland, Sullivan, Westchester and Ulster counties, and on Long Island, and allegations that Trinity lacked basic documentation for Medicaid claims it submitted or proof it delivered Synagis.

Company: Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania Health System

Description: The Louisiana Attorney General's Office announced that it had obtained a total of $88 million in settlements from 25 pharmaceutical companies to resolve allegations they overcharged the state's Medicaid program.

UPS agreed to pay $4 million to resolves multistate allegations that certain employees violated false claims act laws by recording inaccurate delivery times on packages sent via next-day delivery services by government customers. That resulted in premium-priced packages that appeared to be delivered by their guaranteed commitment times when, in fact, they were not.

United States Fidelity & Guaranty agreed to pay $17.5 million to settle claims that DeFelice, Inc. installed defective storm drains on Interstate-84. USF&G was the provider of the contractor's performance bond.

Company: United States Fidelity and Guaranty Co.
Description: United States Fidelity and Guaranty Co., a subsidiary of Travelers Insurance, agreed to forfeit a $2.9 million claim against the Massachusetts Department of Transportation and pay $25,000 costs in settlement of allegations it sought payment for recovery of costs that were inflated estimates, or for which it had been fully compensated, or costs whose recovery was prohibited under the contract.

Universal Health Services paid the state $3.3 million to the state to settle allegation it provided sub-standard psychiatric care to adolescents in violation of federal and state Medicaid requirements, falsified records to cover up their serious violations and filed false Medicaid claims. This was part of a larger $6.85 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/va-universal-health-services-inc
University of Chicago Medical Center agreed to pay to settle allegations it violated licensing regulations by exceeding its patient capacity.

The University of Illinois agreed to pay $2 million to settle a lawsuit alleging it falsely diagnosed patients to allow them to become eligible sooner for liver transplants, increasing the amount of Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement it recieved. The State of Illinois received $751,234, of which $250,4115 was paid to the whistleblower. The case was also reported by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/il-university-of-illinois-at-chicago-medica

O'Neill, Finnegan & Jordan, a Boston insurance brokerage firm, and Unum Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of UnumProvident Corp., agreed to jointly pay $1.3 million in settlement of allegations that Unum's commission payment to OFJ when arranging state contracts was illegal. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between hem.
falsification of wholesale drug price reporting
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Recovers $10.9 Million for State of Texas, Targeted News Service, February 13, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.

URS Corp. agreed to pay $2.3 million in settlement of allegations if submitted false and inflated invoices during the renovation of Logan International Airport. This was in addition to the $1 million paid by URS Corp. before the litigation.

Company: UST Development, Inc. dba US-Telecom, Inc.
Description: Company was ordered to pay a $132,000 civil penalty in default judgment of allegations it sent false invoices to state agencies and local governments.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.

Company: Vascuscript, Inc., d/b/a Mobile Pharmacy Solutions

Description: Verizon agreed to pay more than $1.3 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged the Commonwealth for telecommunications services under a statewide procurement contract.

Verizon agreed to pay more than $800,000 in interest, penalties and costs in settlement of allegations it overcharged numerous cities and towns for telephone services provided under a statewide contract. It had already refunded the $1.5 million alleged overcharged amount.
Victory Human Services agreed to pay $548,000 in settlement of allegations it fraudulently charged Medicaid for Adult Foster Care services .

Company: Visiting Nurse Service of New York
Parent Company: Visiting Nurse Service of New York

Description: VNA of Middlesex-East agreed to pay $88,990 to Medicaid after overpayments were discovered during an in-house audit.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.

Walgreens agreed to pay $16.4 million to settle multistate claims that from 2001 to 2005 it improperly switched patients to different versions of the prescription drugs Ranitidine, Fluoxetine and Eldepryl in order to increase its reimbursement from Medicaid. This was part of a larger $35 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreen-co

Walgreens agreed to pay $3.79 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it  violated anti-kickback and false claims laws by enrolling hundreds of thousands of beneficiaries of government healthcare programs in its Prescription Savings Club program with discounts and other monetary incentives, in order to induce them to patronize Walgreen pharmacies for all of their prescription drug needs. This was part of a larger $50 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreen-co-2
The Walgreen Co. agreed to pay $140,000 in settlement of allegations it double-billed for some prescriptions that were eligible for both Medicaid and Medicare.
overbilling for prescription drugs

National retail pharmacy chain Walgreens agreed to pay $9.9 million to four states -- Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan and Minnesota -- and the federal government to resolve allegations of falsely billing the Medicaid program with regard to customers that also had private third-party coverage. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-1

Walgreens agreed to pay approximately $600,00 to settle multistate litigation alleging it offered illegal inducements to beneficiaries of government health care programs to transfer their prescriptions to its pharmacies. This was part of a larger $7.9 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-0

The California Attorney General announced a $9.8 million settlement with Walgreens to resolve allegations that it failed to adhere fully to requirements imposed by California law for the dispensing of certain prescriptions drugs under Medi-Cal.
Walgreens agreed to pay $5.5 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged for prescription drugs covered by the state workers' compensation insurance system.
Walgreens agreed to pay $2.8 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged public entities for prescription drugs under the workers' compensation insurance system.

Walgreens Boots Alliance agreed to pay $41.2 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it engaged in fraudulent conduct when it dispensed insulin pens. Walgreens was alleged to have not always adhered to the dosage outlined by the prescribing doctor, but rather dispensed insulin pens in boxes containing five pens, regardless of the patient's needs. This resulted in a pattern where beneficiaries were routinely receiving more insulin than prescribed and Walgreens was then billing Medicaid for the additional doses. At the same time, Walgreens agreed to pay $28 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it overcharged Medicaid by failing to disclose discounts offered to customers. These cases were part of two larger settlements  totaling $269 million involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-walgreens-boots-alliance-inc-0
Walmart agreed to pay $207,000 in settlement of allegations it overcharged public entities for prescription drugs under the workers' compensation insurance system.

Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. agreed to pay $2,866,904 to a group of states and the federal government to settle allegations that it submitted false prescription claims to government health insurance programs by dispensing partial prescriptions due to insufficient stock while billing for the full quantities. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-wal-mart-stores-inc-1

Warner Chilcott agreed to pay $10.6 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it promoted several of its drugs for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration and thus caused false claims to be submitted to state Medicaid programs. This was part of a larger $125 million civil and criminal settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-warner-chilcott-plc

Company: Warrick Pharmaceuticals Corp. and Schering-Plough Corp.
Description: Warrick Pharmaceuticals Corporation and Schering-Plough Corp. agreed to pay a total of $750,000 in settlement of allegations they misreported the average wholesale price of their drugs.
Misleading reporting on wholesale drug prices, inflating costs for Medicaid.

Company: Washington East of the River Academy (WEALTHY)
Description: WEALTHY, its principal and its accountant were found guilty of unlawfully diverty District grant funds intended for a 2009 summer youth program.

Watson Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $70 million to Florida, Texas and local governments in New York to resolve allegations that it knowingly set and reported false and inflated prices for medications dispensed by pharmacies and other providers who were then reimbursed by state Medicaid programs.
Info Source: Attorney General Bondi's Office Recovers $20.2 Million for Florida from Pharmaceutical Company in Medicaid Fraud Settlement, States News Service, September 16, 2011 (via Nexis).

Company: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Watson Pharma Inc.
Description: Watson Pharmaceuticals, Inc. and Watson Pharma, Inc. agreed to pay $1.7 million in settlement of allegations they misreported the average wholesale price of their drugs.
Watson Pharmaceuticals, Inc. agreed to pay over $2.4 million in settlement of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to pay inflated amounts.
Watson, Inc. was ordered to pay more than $33 million in judgment of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to pay inflated amounts.
Falsification of wholesale drug price reporting. Federal government shared in the settlement. Penalty amount listed here is state portion only.
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Recovers $11.3 Million for Texas Medicaid Program, Targeted News Service, September 27, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.

WellCare Health Plans Inc. agreed to pay $137.5 million to nine states and the federal government to resolve four lawsuits alleging violations of the False Claims Act by falsely inflating the amount it claimed to be spending on medical care in order to avoid returning money to Medicaid and other programs in various states. The settlement was also announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-wellcare-health-plans-inc

WellStar Health Systems agreed to pay $2.738 million in settlement of allegations about WellStar's billing for cross-over claims, which are claims made for patients who are enrolled in both Medicare and Medicaid.  Medicare acts as the primary coverage, with Medicaid functioning as the secondary insurance, and Medicaid has a cap on the amount of reimbursement that a hospital can receive.  The investigation found that WellStar filed claims which did not reflect the full amount of Medicare prior payments, allowing WellStar to receive excessive Medicaid reimbursements.

Bechtel/Parsons Brinkerhoff, Bechtel Infrastructure Corp, PB Americas and 24 section design consultants agreed to pay a total of $447 million in settlement of criminal and civil liablities in the collapse of part of the I-90 tunnel and defects in the wall of the Tip O'Neill tunnel. Bechtel was to pay $357.1 million and Parsons $50 million. The announcement did not indicate how the remaining $40 million payment would be divided among the consultants. Here we assume each paid an equal amount.
Falsification of wholesale drug price reporting. Federal government shared in the settlement. Penalty amount listed here is state portion only.
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Recovers $10 Million for State of Texas, U.S., Targeted News Service, April 29, 2014 (via Nexis).

Description: Arbitrators ordered White Oak to pay $1.1 million primarily for repeated construction delays when its contract to rebuild the Tomlinson Bridge could not be completed on time and was turned over to another company.

The Ohio Development Services Agency, the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority, and the Ohio Attorney General's Office announced that the three agencies reached a $6.5 million settlement with a Perrysburg manufacturing company for unpaid loans.

Willow Street Laboratories agreed to pay $8.15 million in settlement of allegations it billed Medicaid for urine drug and alcohol tests that were inappropriately ordered for non-medical purposes and made inappropriate payments to a third party to obtain Medicaid business.
Wollaston Dental Care and its owner agreed to pay $750,000 in settlement of allegations it improperly billed Medicaid for emergency dental services.

Wyeth and its parent Pfizer agreed to pay $371 million to resolve multistate allegations that Wyeth knowingly reported to Medicaid agencies false and fraudulent prices on two of its proton pump inhibitor drugs, Protonix Oral and Protonix IV. This was part of a larger $784 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-pfizer-inc-2
inflated expenses

Company: Zurich American Insurance Company et al.
Description: Zurich agreed to pay $37.5 million to settle claims relating to workers compensation surcharges.
submission of claims for services supervised by physicians not enrolled in Medicaid

Company: Jewish Hospital & St. Mary's Healthcare Inc.
Sacramento Cardiovascular Surgeons Medical Group Inc.

Description: ABS Development Corporation agreed to pay $2.8 million and give up $16 million in potential administrative claims to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by fraudulently obtaining a foreign military sales contract reserved for American companies.  ABS, a Delaware corporation based in New York, is a subsidiary of Ashtrom International, Ltd. of Israel.

Fagron Holding USA LLC agreed to pay $22.05 million to resolve allegations concerning the establishment of false and inflated Average Wholesale Prices by its wholly owned subsidiary Freedom Pharmaceuticals Inc. for active pharmaceutical ingredients used in compound prescriptions.  Freedom's pricing scheme caused pharmacies that purchased is compound ingredients to submit false prescription claims to the Defense Health Agency, which administers the TRICARE Program for the Department of Defense and the Department of Labor's Office of Workers Compensation Programs.

Seven former Osteo Relief Institutes and their owners agreed to pay the United States collectively more than $7.1 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations that they knowingly billed Medicare for medically unnecessary viscosupplementation injections and medically unnecessary knee braces.

Avanir Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $103 million to resolve civil False Claims Act allegations ($95.972 million to the federal government and $7 million to the states) and $12.8 million to resolve criminal kickback allegations in a case involving payments to physicians to induce prescriptions of its drug Nuedexta.

Company: Diabetic Care Rx LLC aka Patient Care America and Riordan, Lewis & Haden Inc.

Description: United Parcel Service Inc. agreed to pay the United States $8.4 million to resolve allegations that it overcharged federal agencies for package delivery services under a General Services Administration (GSA) contract.

The Illinois Attorney General Kwame announced the recovery of $242 million in a settlement with numerous drug companies resolving allegations the companies inflated the wholesale prices used in setting the rates for Medicaid reimbursements.

Description: Reckitt Benckiser agreed to pay $400 million to state governments to resolve litigation involving improper marketing of the opioid addiction treatment drug Suboxone. This was part of a larger $1.3 billion criminal and civil settlement also involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-reckitt-benckiser-group-plc-0

Secondary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Avanir Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $7 million to the states to resolve civil False Claims Act relating to payments made to physicians to induce prescriptions of its drug Nuedexta. This was part of a larger $115 million civil and criminal settlement involving the federal governmen (see separate entry).

Kaleida Health, the largest not-for-profit health care provider in Western New York, agreed to pay $500,000 to resolve an investigation into the death of a 16-month-old pediatric resident in 2015, as well as the previous arrests of 17 caregivers in 2014, who were subsequently convicted of neglect of a resident with Huntington's disease at the HighPointe on Michigan Health Care Facility in Buffalo.
Lupin Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $63 million to resolve litigation brought under the Texas Medicaid Fraud Prevention Act for reporting inflated drug prices to the Medicaid program.
Eagle Alliance, a Northrop Grumman partnership, paid the United States $110,000 to resolve False Claims Act allegations that it improperly billed the government for computer hardware.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Company: Health Care Options, Inc. et al.

Description: Two foundations, Chronic Disease Fund, Inc. dba Good Days from CDF and Patient Access Network Foundation agreed to pay $2 million and $4 million, respectively, to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by enabling pharmaceutical companies to pay kickbacks to Medicare patients taking the companies' drugs.

Two foundations, Chronic Disease Fund, Inc. dba Good Days from CDF and Patient Access Network Foundation agreed to pay $2 million and $4 million, respectively, to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by enabling pharmaceutical companies to pay kickbacks to Medicare patients taking the companies' drugs.

Description: Fresenius agreed to pay $5.2 million to resolve allegations that the company tested dialysis patients for Hepatitis B surface antigen more frequently than medically necessary and then billed Medicare for the unnecessary tests.

Description: Mellon Bank, N.A. entered into a Settlement Agreement regarding the April 2001 destruction of over 77,000 tax returns and payments at the Mellon Client Service Center in Pittsburgh.
Info Source: Mellon Bank Enters Settlement Agreemen Over Destroyed Tax Returns, US Fed News, August 18, 2006 (via Nexis).

Company: University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey

Description: The San Francisco City Attorney and the California State Attorney General announced that Pick Your Part Auto Wrecking, dba City Tow, agreed to pay $5.7 million in settlement of allegations it operated a scheme that sold towed, unclaimed cars for scrap to itself rather than auctioning them off to cover costs and paying the remainder to the State.

Murphy/Jahn agreed to pay $1.9 million to settle its role in litigation stemming from faulty design and construction of a terminal facade project at O'Hare Airport that was supposed to provide more interior space and shield air travelers from the elements.
Info Source: $21 Million Settlement for Fault O'Hare Work, Chicago Sun-Times, March 8, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Walsh Construction agreed to pay $10 million to settle its role in litigation stemming from faulty design and construction of a terminal facade project at O'Hare Airport that was supposed to provide more interior space and shield air travelers from the elements.
Info Source: $21 Million Settlement for Fault O'Hare Work, Chicago Sun-Times, March 8, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: Cole Hardware pleaded guilty to charges of defrauding the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission and was ordered to pay restitution of $51,544 and approximately $650 in penalties and costs.
Agency: City and County of San Francisco (CA) District Attorney

Description: Best Care Home Health Services ordered by an arbitrator to pay the Hennepin County Metropolitan Health Plan approximately $690,000 in a ruling of allegations by both sides that they were in breach of contracts for blood tests. The arbitrator ruled that Best Care had defrauded MHP by billing for blood draws that were not performed

Fleishman-Hillard agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the city of Los Angeles over the public relations firm's work for the Department of Water and Power; the company also waived payment of about $1.2 million in unpaid DWP invoices.
Info Source: PR Giant Agrees to $5.7 Million Settlement with City, City News Service, April 19, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: UCRA pleaded no contest to one felony count of misuse of public funds and agreed to return $2.4 million and cancel $800,000 in billing following allegations it obtained contracts from the Department of Public Social Services by false representation and billed for employment-related services that were never provided.

I-Lite Electric and its principals pleaded guilty to Grand Larceny in the Second Degree in connection with allegations it fraudulently overstated the cost for materials used in work for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Jadeite, along with its owners, pleaded guilty to charges of defrauding the Port Authority of New York and the New Jersey and New York City School Construction Authority by submitting false invoices.
Bovis agreed to pay $5 million to New York City to resolve allegations about overcharges on construction projects.
Info Source: Contractor and City Settle Overcharges for $5 Million, New York Times, January 6, 2011 (via Nexis).
$70,000 settlement is reached in airport contracts suit; Company, 2 execs agree to pay city, San Diego Union-Tribune, June 7, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: The San Diego City Attorney's Office recovered $4.95 million in the settlement of a lawsuit brought against a contractor accused of defective installation on a sewer project.
Info Source: SD Contractor Settlement, City News Service, May 3, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Office Depot agreed to pay $4.25 million in settlement of allegations it overcharged San Francisco by failing to provide contractually mandated discounts on items ordered by the city.
ES&S agreed to pay $3.5 million to the City and County of San Francisco in settlement of allegations its voting machines caused additional costs in order to meet certification requirements.

Inter-Tel Technologies agreed to pay over $1 million to the San Francisco Unified School District as part of the settlement of allegations of false claims, bribery and bid-rigging with other companies to win contracts to supply computer service and hardware to schools at inflated prices. The company pleaded guilty to two felony counts in the accompanying criminal case. This was part of a larger $8.7 million settlement with the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-inter-tel-technologies-inc
The San Francisco Unified School District won a $43.1 million settlement in a lawsuit filed against a North Carolina company that was supposed to help the district save money on energy charges.
Info Source: SF schools win $43.1 settlement against energy company, Associated Press, July 1, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: NEC agreed to pay more than $3 million to the San Francisco Unified School District as part of a settlement of allegations of false claims, bribery and bid-rigging with other companies to win contracts to supply computer service and hardware to schools at inflated prices. The company pleaded guilty to two felony counts in the accompanying criminal case. This was part of a larger $20 million settlement with the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-nec-business-network-solutions-inc

U.S. Machinery was ordered to pay $200,000 restitution to the San Francisco Unified School District in one of the lawsuits resulting from investigation of fraud and bid-rigging by numerous technology vendors and consultants involved in the federal E-Rate program providing certain computer related equipment and services.
Electronic Data Systems agreed to pay $3.4 million to resolve an investigation into whether the company's insurance subsidiary overcharged the state for managing its Medicaid program.
Info Source: Contractor to pay state $3.4 million; EDS resolves inquiry into possible Medicaid overcharges but doesn't admit to any wrongdoing, Austin American-Statesman, June 7, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: Jet Vac agreed to pay $158,226 in restitution and its former general manager agreed to pay $129,000  in civil penalties and costs, for which the company was also liable for and paid, in settlement of allegations it over-billed municipalities and other public entities, charging more than permitted under its state contract.
Agency: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs
Interior Department Office of Natural Resources Revenue

Description: The Boeing Company, General Dynamics Corporation, and the United States formally asked the United States Court of Federal Claims to dismiss, as part of a settlement, their 23-year old dispute involving the Department of the Navy's 1991 default termination of a $4.8 billion contract awarded to Boeing's predecessor, McDonnell Douglas Corporation, and General Dynamics, to develop the A-12 carrier-based stealth aircraft. Under the settlement, the contractors agreed to provide aircraft and services to the military valued at $400 millionand the government would not pay any money in connection with the contractors' claims against the United States.

The Boeing Company, General Dynamics Corporation, and the United States formally asked the United States Court of Federal Claims to dismiss, as part of a settlement, their 23-year old dispute involving the Department of the Navy's 1991 default termination of a $4.8 billion contract awarded to Boeing's predecessor, McDonnell Douglas Corporation, and General Dynamics, to develop the A-12 carrier-based stealth aircraft. Under the settlement, the contractors agreed to provide aircraft and services to the military valued at $400 millionand the government would not pay any money in connection with the contractors' claims against the United States.

Shell Oil agreed to pay the United States $56 million to resolve claims that it underpaid royalties owed on natural gas produced from federal leases. The settlement resolved allegations that Shell systematically underreported the value of natural gas that it produced on federal leases in the Gulf of Mexico from August 1, 1986 to December 31, 1999 and, consequently, paid less royalties than it owed to the government.

Description: Hybrid Tech Holdings, LLC, Hybrid Technology, LLC, and Ace Strength International, LTD, agreed to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by colluding to rig the bidding of an auction to purchase the United States Department of Energy's non-performing loan to Fisker Automotive, Inc. and Fisker Automotive Holdings, Inc.

ResMed Corp., a manufacturer of durable medical equipment for sleep apnea and other sleep-related disorders, agreed to pay more than $37.5 million to resolve allegations under the False Claims Act for paying kickbacks to suppliers, sleep labs, and other health care providers.

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Middle District of North Carolina

Description: Boston Heart Diagnostics Corporation agreed to pay $26.67 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations involving payments for patient referrals in violation of the Anti-Kickback Statute and the Stark Law and claims otherwise improperly billed to federal health care programs for laboratory testing.

Guardian Elder Care Holdings Inc., and related companies Guardian LTC Management Inc., Guardian Elder Care Management Inc., Guardian Elder Care Management I Inc., and Guardian Rehabilitation Services Inc., agreed to pay $15,466,278 to resolve False Claims Act allegations that they knowingly overbilled Medicare and the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program for medically unnecessary rehabilitation therapy services.

Tenet Healthcare Corporation and its affiliated hospital Desert Regional Medical Center (DRMC), a general medical and surgical hospital located in Palm Springs, California, agreed to pay $1.41 million to resolve allegations that they violated the False Claims Act by knowingly charging Medicare for implanting unnecessary cardiac monitors.

CRA/LA agreed to pay $3.1 million to resolve allegations that its predecessor violated the False Claims Act by knowingly failing to comply with federal accessibility laws when it financed and assisted in the development of affordable housing in the City of Los Angeles supported by federal funds.

Unitrans International Inc., a privately held Virginia defense contracting company, agreed to pay $45 million to resolve criminal obstruction charges and civil False Claims Act allegations relating to the illegal transportation of goods across Iran in connection with a contract to provide material and logistical support to U.S. troops in Afghanistan.

Avalign Technologies, Inc. and its subsidiary Instrumed International, Inc. agreed to pay $9.5 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging violations of federal and state False Claims Acts by selling medical devices that were not approved or cleared by the FDA. The settlement was also announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-avalign-technologies-inc
